PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2079-07-28
MIDLAND EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
NOONAN,FRANKIE 516-39-35-7 VISIT DATE: 07/28/79
The patient was interviewed and examined by myself along with the
resident, Dr. Welsh. Please see his note for full details.
HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: In brief, a 60 year-old male
complaining of shortness of breath. Ran out of his Lasix about 5-6
days ago and now is with increasing lower extremity edema,
orthopnea, PND. Denies fever, chills, nausea or vomiting. Sent
here for evaluation by his PCP today.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No palpitations, no diaphoresis.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus,
hypertension, coronary artery disease, and atrial fibrillation.
MEDICATIONS: Insulin, Glucophage, Verapamil, Lasix, Relafen, and
Coumadin.
ALLERGIES: No known drug allergies.
SOCIAL HISTORY AND FAMILY HISTORY: Does not drink, does not smoke.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITAL SIGNS: Blood pressure 136/88, O2
saturation 95 percent, heart rate 54, temperature 97.8. GENERAL:
Well-developed, well-nourished male in no apparent distress,
denying chest pain at this time. HEENT: Normocephalic,
atraumatic. Pupils were equal, round and reactive to light.
Extraocular muscles full. NECK: No evidence of jugular venous
distension. Supple. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation. HEART:
Regular rate and rhythm. Normal S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs or
gallops. ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender and non-distended. Active
bowel sounds. EXTREMITIES: 3+ pedal edema. NEUROLOGIC: Cranial
nerves II-XII grossly intact. Alert and oriented times three.
Motor 5/5. Sensation intact to light touch throughout.
LABORATORY EVALUATION: Basic labs included a white count of 6.9,
hematocrit 39, BUN and creatinine of 10 and 1.0, with a potassium
of 5.7. CK was 186, troponin 0.04. Amylase was 61. Blood sugar
was 253. Chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly. EKG showed atrial
fibrillation at about 50. Nonspecific ST-T wave changes.
THERAPY RENDERED/COURSE IN ED: Differential of his shortness of
breath includes congestive heart failure, ischemia. He was
admitted to the hospital for training of his congestive heart
failure regimen. His primary M.D. was notified.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
1. Shortness of breath.
2. Congestive heart failure.
DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): He was admitted
in stable condition.
___________________________________ CQ102/93848
ROSE R. WALSH, M.D. RW88 D:09/04/79
T:09/05/79
Dictated by: ROSE R. WALSH, M.D. RW88

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2081-10-02
Spanish 69 Sheffield Road NOONAN, FRANCE Burkburnett, NE 97618 51639357 (842) 544-2703 10/02/81
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Mr. Noonan is a 69-year-old man who has type II insulin-requiring diabetes, obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic atrial fibrillation, degenerative osteoarthritis and diabetic neuropathy.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: He comes today complaining of one week with mild chest pain not irradiated to the head, to jaw or the arm, but with very mild shortness of breath. He denies nausea, vomiting or sweatiness.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Protonix 40 mg p.o. b.i.d., verapamil SR 190 mg q.d., Lasix 20 mg p.o. q.d., Neurontin 900 mg in the morning 900 mg at noon and 300 mg at night, Lipitor 10 mg q.d., Zestril 10 mg q.d., Glucophage 1000 mg twice a day, and 75/25 insulin 40 units in the morning and 40 in the evening, Tylenol with Codeine p.r.n. for severe pain and Coumadin 3 mg alternating with 4.5 mg.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The blood pressure today is 120/88 and his weight is 256 pounds. The examination of the neck with no lymph nodes. He is oriented and in no acute distress. The cardiac examination with arrhythmia consistent with atrial fibrillation. The lungs with hypoventilation in both bases and no evidence of acute congestive heart failure. He has edema that has been chronic in both extremities.
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Review of an EKG obtained in August of this year showed atrial fibrillation with premature ventricular or apparently conducted complexes, nonspecific T-wave abnormality probably digitalis effect, abnormal EKG that when compared to the one in June showed nonspecific T-wave abnormalities that were not evident at that time and now present in anterior leads.
I have talked to people in the emergency department and he is being sent right now for an evaluation of possible angina.
______________________________ DANNY WOODY, M.D.

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2082-10-01
EDVISIT^51639357^Noonan, France^10/01/82^ELROD, RYLEY
This patient was seen on 10/01/2082 with the resident, Dr.
Jacob. Please see her note for details. The resident's
history and physical examination were reviewed and confirmed.
Please see her note for details. The plan of care and
disposition of the patient were discussed with the resident.
IMPRESSION: This is a 70-year-old male who presents with two
weeks of back pain radiating from the mid back to the chest. He
also has pain in his left leg up to his flank. He also has some
scrotal swelling and lower abdominal pain. The pain has been
intermittent and the patient has been taking Vicodin for the past
two days. The pain that he has been having is actually chronic,
except for the left-sided flank pain and the chest pain. He was
found on the ground by his daughter, and it was unclear to the
patient how he ended up in that position.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Significant for myocardial infarction,
atrial fibrillation, diabetes, cerebrovascular accident, low back
pain, sciatica, Bell palsy, reflux, osteochondritis, peripheral
vascular disease, and diabetic neuropathy.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is afebrile, heart rate 80,
respirations 16, blood pressure 126/82, and oxygen saturation is
100%. He is in severe distress. His lung exam is normal. His
cardiac examination shows no abnormality. His abdomen is
distended, and there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower
quadrant, and there is CVA tenderness in the left flank. There
is also significant pain on movement of his left leg either
passively or actively. It is not possible for us to evaluate the
strength in his left hip or knee because of pain. He is alert
and oriented to person, place, time, and event. His cranial
nerves are intact. Rectal examination shows mildly decreased
sphincter tone, but no evidence of saddle anesthesia.
LABORATORY STUDIES: Show a CK of 128 with MB fraction of 3.8,
and troponin I is less than assay. INR is 2.8. UA shows 0 to 1
white blood cells and 1 to 2 red blood cells. Electrocardiogram
shows atrial fibrillation with bradycardic rate of 47. His head
CT shows no abnormality. There is stranding around his left
kidney. The aorta appears normal.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: The patient was given an aspirin
325 mg p.o. and morphine 4 mg IV for pain. His pain improved
significantly. However, he had another recurrence of the pain
and with rising discomfort. It was decided to admit the patient
to the hospital for management of his pain and further workup to
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
markedly bradycardic.

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2085-07-25
EDVISIT^51639357^NOONAN, FRANCE^07/25/85^ELROD, RYLEY
This patient was seen with Dr. Ussery. I confirm that I have
interviewed and examined the patient, reviewed the resident's
documentation on the patient's chart, and discussed the
evaluation, plan of care, and disposition with the patient.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 73-year-old male with a
history of cough and pleuritic type chest pain. The patient
denies any nausea or vomiting. He does have history of MI as
well as multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease. He
also reports lower extremities swelling worse than usual, and has
left greater than right edema at baseline due to a reconstructive
surgery following motor vehicle collision. Of note, the
patient's medications include Coumadin, which he is on for atrial
fibrillation.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is awake, alert, and in no
distress. His vital signs show heart rate of 70, respiratory
rate of 24, blood pressure 112/72, and oxygen saturation 96% on
room air and 98% on 2 liters. His lungs are clear and heart is
irregularly irregular. This is somewhat limited due to body
habitus. The abdomen is soft and there is a chronic left upper
quadrant tenderness. The back shows left CVA tenderness.
LABORATORY DATA: The laboratory analysis shows a hematocrit of
42.1 and a white blood cell count of 7.6. Cardiac biomarkers are
negative, and the troponin is less than 0.1. A d-dimer is less
than 200. The INR is 1.7. UA is pending. ECG shows an atrial
fibrillation with some nonspecific T-wave changes in leads V3
through V6.
IMAGING STUDIES: A chest radiograph was a markedly limited due
to patient's habitus.
DECISION MAKING AND EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: There was no
clear etiology to the patient's shortness of breath. Given his
anticoagulation and a negative d-dimer, we feel that this is
unlikely to be PE. It is clearly possible to be cardiac, given
the history of coronary artery disease and a slightly abnormal
electrocardiogram. This may be pneumonia, and the chest x-ray is
not terribly helpful. We are obtaining a CT scan of the chest
without IV contrast to better delineate the pulmonary
architecture, and are admitting the patient to the Medicine
Service for monitoring and cycling of enzymes and ECGs.
DIAGNOSES:
1. Shortness of breath.
2. T-wave inversions on electrocardiogram.
______________________________
ELROD, RYLEY M.D.

T: 07/25/85

HPI: 76 year old Spanish speaking male with numerous medical problems (IDDM, Afib, HTN, PVD, Cr baseline 1.7, no prior HF,, normal echo 2085, normal MIBI 2085) who was just dishcharged 28 days ago for LE edema admission, who complains of 3 weeks of sore throat. He states that because of this he has suffered from a gradual dyspnea, complicated by orthopnea and PND for two days. He states he has left sided pleuritic chest pain worse with inspiration. He states he also has noticed increased baseline LE edema for 2 weeks, but denies and increase in abdominal girth. He states he decided to seek medical treatment for his gradual onset shortness of breath.
The patient states he has been taking all of his medications and has not increased the sodium in his diet recently. He denies fever, chills, dysuria, asymettric leg swelling, or any palpable blood vessels in his legs.
Of note the patient is on 80 mg BID of lasix for his LE edema though his most recent echo, 2085, shows a normal EF and the patient has no history of CHF.
